captions.text: Guide us to the Straight Path
Financial Freedom
When currencies were first developed, people relied on natural resources
Rare items had more value as a currency and were used for bartering and trade
In Mexico, for example, coffee beans were a form of currency
One of the oldest types of currency was shells
Societies then began to use gold as a currency
Gold was used as a currency because people gave it value
Gold has been used as a currency by human societies since ancient times
Let's look at the relationship between gold and the US dollar
After the United States was established, a gold standard was established,
to regulate the production of print money and make it convertible to gold
Each ounce of gold was set to equal 16 US dollars
The gold standard regulated the value of the dollar
Let's review at the historical relationship between the two
From 1792 until the early 20th century the ratio was consistent at $16 an ounce
In the early 20th century there were some problems related to the Great Depression
but the price ratio remained, to some extent, consistent
This ratio ended in 1971
The United States was involved in the Vietnam War at the time
Funding the war imposed a significant burden on the Treasury
Nixon announced:
So he suspended the convertibility of gold to the dollar to fund the war
This enabled the country to print more paper money which led to inflation
Since then the price of gold has fluctuated, and risen, compared to US dollars
Today, one ounce of gold now is valued at around 1200 US dollars.
Ford T models, like this one, were popular cars in America in the 1920s
At the time, a new Ford would cost you 400 US dollars
That would amount to 20 ounces of gold
In 2014, a car from the same company [Ford] would cost you 26 thousand US dollars
What's bizarre, though, is that the price of this new car in gold is the same as what a Ford T model cost almost 100 years ago: 20 ounces
The lesson learned here is that gold maintains the same value over time
So even if the value of the US dollar, like other currencies in the past, deteriorates, with gold you maintain the same value
This is where dollars are printed
They get invoices to print out dollars every day
[According to him], the cost of printing 100 dollars is 13 cents
The Federal Reserve invoices 13 cents for every 100 dollars printed
This means that the government controls the value of print money
Your relationship, therefore, is built on trust only because the paper in itself doesn't have any value
If populations lose confidence in their governments, they will also lose confidence in the currency of that government
Some people think [incorrectly] that printing more money makes a country richer
But the more you print of a currency, the less valuable it becomes and the less purchasing power it has
Imagine that, across history, 3800 currencies have become defunct due to lack of value and inflation
One example is Zimbabwe
In 2008, the currency collapsed. So much printing occurred that, due to inflation, prices doubled every 24 hours
For example, if one day bread cost 1 dollar
It would become 2 dollars the very next day
The day after it would cost 4 dollars
The day after, 8 dollars
By the end of the year, the price of one loaf of bread was 35 million Zimbabwe dollar
It was a complete collapse to the extent the currency was no longer used
The situation in Zimbabwe reached a point where people used gold to buy bread
So the whole system was transformed back to [a currency] that has value
Why? The population did not trust the government printing their currency
whereas gold continues to be a trustworthy commodity because its value is not tied to governments
The floor of this restaurant corridor is made entirely of pennies
Approximately 3500 pennies make up the floor of this corridor
That amounts to 35 pounds
This would never happen in the early 20th century because pennies had significant value
35 pounds in the [early] 1900s would pay four months' rent
35 pounds doesn't even cover one day's rent nowadays
There's nothing you can buy now with a penny today in the UK
We all want to reach financial freedom by retirement
What does financial freedom mean though?
Some think that you need to accumulate a lot of wealth to be financially free
That's incorrect though because it will disappear from spending and you have financial freedom
To achieve financial independence you need to have a significant number of assets
and these assets should bring in more income than your spending.
Real estate is one of the best long term investments
For example in the US, historically housing prices have consistently increased
There have been some fluctuations and short term downturns
Even in 2008, at the time of the financial crisis, there was a downturn but by 2013 house prices began to rise
So in the long term, real estate is one of the best investments
In California, for example, a house that cost 125,000 in 2000 would be valued (in 2013) at 225,000
Some people assume that you need to have millions of dollars to invest in real estate
Some low cost options include purchasing storage space and renting it out
You can buy one for around 5,000-10,000 [Saudi] riyals and it will give you monthly returns
Financial experts distinguish between the cost of an item and its opportunity cost
For example, a cellphone would cost you around 3000 [Saudi] riyals
If you decided to invest that money instead, though, at 21
By the time you turn 65, you would have 250,000 riyals
So the opportunity cost of the phone amounts to a quarter million riyals
Financially savvy people know when something is worth buying and when it is better to forgo a purchase and invest instead
Gold was discovered near the West Coast of the USA in what is referred to as the 'Gold Rush'
Just a quick note: only about a thousand people lived in this area in the 19th century [before the Gold Rush]
The discovery of gold and the Gold Rush helped establish California as one of the most important states
This is the first sifting stage
We found gold!
Out of all of the silt we sifted through, we found these two tiny pieces of gold
Let's go see how much this is worth
What makes gold so valuable that we spent an hour sifting through the river silt to find these tiny pieces?
Gold is valuable because it is rare and the more rare an item is, the higher its worth
It's estimated that all the gold that's been extracted from the Earth since the beginning of human history until today
if melted would only fill three Olympic size pools if melted so the resource base is very limited
and because it is limited it has a lot of value
Let's go see how valuable these tiny nuggets are
68 dollars? That's good for an hour's effort
An emerging trend in the East and West is Gold ATM machines
These days you might stumble across an ATM machine- not for cash, but for gold. This one, for example, is in New York
We're in the UAE now, Gold ATMs are available in Abu Dhabi and Dubai
These are 10 grams of silver
The idea is that when you have some extra cash or savings to save and buy gold or silver
In this machine, the least amount you can purchase is silver for 240 dirhams
You can buy as much as you can afford
[Proverb] A small but everlasting amount [of something] is better than having a lot of something without consistency
If you buy gold today and the price goes down tomorrow, don't say that Khawater deceived me.
The price of gold is bound to fluctuate, naturally.
But buy gold with the intention of a long term investment; for 5, 10, 15 years for you and your heirs
Warren Buffet, the second richest man on the planet, accumulated his vast wealth through investing in the stock market
He was born to a middle class family but began investing at a young age
We're now at an American college campus. Brad, who is an investor, studies here and lives in the dorms.
Wow, he's programmed his day around the stock market
We need to teach our children the value of investing at a young age.
Just as a reminder, you shouldn't look at investments for short term gains
I don't want viewers to get enthusiastic and invest in something they haven't studied
One of the best long-term investments is investing in stocks
This graph conveys the growth in stocks in the US market
Over this period in time, the value in stocks has increased by 1500%
Take into consideration that this huge increase in value occurred over a long period of time
There are also fluctuations in the stock market over short-term periods, which is natural
You shouldn't invest in the stock market with money that you will need in a short period of time
You need to have a long-term vision of at least 5 to 10 years; and thats's where we see the growth in value [in the chart]
Monopoly captures the essence of what it means to be financially savvy
How does one win in Monopoly?
The player who wins in Monopoly is always the one who invests in land,
builds houses and hotels, and gets returns when people land on their property and consequently gets rich
Players that continue to accumulate wealth without investing in land look like they're going to win
but they end up losing because they lose their fortune by paying 'rent' to other players and taking loans from the bank
This is a valuable lesson to learn: don't collect cash only.
Whenever you have extra money, invest it
Invest in, [for example]: real estate, stocks, gold or silver

السلام عليكم ورحمة الله وبركاته.. 
مع احترامي وحبي الشديد للعبقري أحمد الشقيري.. 
إلا إنه العقار والأسهم في المملكة العربية السعودية بالذات لازم تسلم على 
فلوسك قبل ما تستثمر فيها وتودعها وداع المحبين.. وداع لا لقاء بعده.. وأما 
الذهب بالنسبة ليه أنا شخصياً ماله قيمة لأن الإنسان ممكن يعيش من دون 
الذهب... 

ووجهة نظري أن التجارة بالمأكولات والمشروبات مربحة جداً وخصوصًا عند شعب كل 
همه بطنه.... 

فمثلاً تجارة المواشي في المناطق التي يتوفر فيها أمطار ومرعى جيد مربحة جداً 
حتى لو فكرت إنك تبيعها في المناطق البعيدة فربحك مضمون بإذن الله تعالى... ﻿
